greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of inequivalent m X n binary matrices, where equivalence means permutations of rows or columns. Presented in diagonal order, with (m,n)=(1,1), (1,2), (2,1), (1,3), (2,2), (3,1), ... .
comment: Same as A028657 without first row and column.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals m = 1..45, flattened
Adalbert Kerber, Applied Finite Group Actions, second edition, Springer-Verlag, (1999). See table under Corollary 2.3.1 on page 68.
Various authors, How many n-by-m binary matrices are there up to row and column permutations
maple: g:= proc(n, k) option remember; add(add(2^add(add(i[2]*j[2]*
seq(seq(A(m, 1+d-m), m=1..d), d=1..12); # _Alois P. Heinz_, Aug 13 2014
mathematica: b[n_, i_] := b[n, i] = If[n == 0, {0}, If[i < 1, {}, Union[Flatten[Table[ Function[{p}, p + j*x^i] /@ b[n - i*j, i - 1], {j, 0, n/i}]]]]];

g[n_, k_] := g[n, k] = Sum[Sum[2^Sum[Sum[GCD[i, j]*Coefficient[s, x, i]* Coefficient[t, x, j], {j, 1, Exponent[t, x]}], {i, 1, Exponent[s, x]}]/ Product[i^Coefficient[s, x, i]*Coefficient[s, x, i]!, {i, 1, Exponent[s, x]}]/Product[i^Coefficient[t, x, i]*Coefficient[t, x, i]!, {i, 1, Exponent[t, x]}], {t, b[n + k, n + k]}], {s, b[n, n]}];
A[n_, k_] := g[Min[n, k], Abs[n - k]];
Table[A[n - k + 1, k], {n, 1, 12}, {k, 1, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 09 2019, after _Alois P. Heinz_ in A028657 *)
results.author: _Don Knuth_, Aug 09 2014
